conclusion: The problem involves finding the temperature of an ideal gas in state C using the Ideal Gas Law.
State A: Pressure \( P_A = 3 \times 10^5 \text{ Pa} \), Volume \( V_A = 2 \times 10^{-3} \text{ m}^3 \), Temperature \( T_A = 27^\circ \text{C} = 300 \text{ K} \).
State B: Pressure \( P_B = 2 \times 10^5 \text{ Pa} \), Volume \( V_B = 2 \times 10^{-3} \text{ m}^3 \).
State C: Pressure \( P_C = 2 \times 10^5 \text{ Pa} \), Volume \( V_C = 3 \times 10^{-3} \text{ m}^3 \).
The Ideal Gas Law is given by \( PV = nRT \).

premise: Using the Ideal Gas Law for State A and State B: \( \frac{P_A V_A}{T_A} = \frac{P_B V_B}{T_B} \).
conclusion: Plugging in the values: \( \frac{(3 \times 10^5 \text{ Pa})(2 \times 10^{-3} \text{ m}^3)}{300 \text{ K}} = \frac{(2 \times 10^5 \text{ Pa})(2 \times 10^{-3} \text{ m}^3)}{T_B} \).

premise: Using the Ideal Gas Law for State B and State C: \( \frac{P_B V_B}{T_B} = \frac{P_C V_C}{T_C} \).
conclusion: Plugging in the values: \( \frac{(2 \times 10^5 \text{ Pa})(2 \times 10^{-3} \text{ m}^3)}{200 \text{ K}} = \frac{(2 \times 10^5 \text{ Pa})(3 \times 10^{-3} \text{ m}^3)}{T_C} \).
